# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

You can solve this problem by creating a function in Julia that filters the data according to your specifications and then adds a new column. Here is an implementation:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = false
    audi_rows = df[(df.manufacturer .== "audi") & (df.model .in ["a4", "a4 quattro"]), :]
    for row in eachrow(audi_rows)
        @inbounds df[row, :audi_a4_type] = true
    end
    return df
end

# Test the function
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
                   model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

After running this code, `df_result` would be a DataFrame that includes an additional column named `audi_a4_type`, where the value is `true` for each row corresponding to an Audi A4 or Audi A4 quattro.
